items.label: Building a real-time Todo app with Drayman, MongoDB and Tailwind CSS

blog/2021-08-17-getting-started-with-dra.title: Getting started with Drayman
blog/2021-08-17-getting-started-with-dra.description: Drayman is a server-side component framework that allows you to use any available HTML element, web component or custom Drayman third-party component together with server-side code in a single script.

blog/2021-08-30-building-real-time-todo-.title: Building a real-time Todo app with Drayman, MongoDB and Tailwind CSS
blog/2021-08-30-building-real-time-todo-.description: In this guide we will build a real-time Todo app with Drayman, MongoDB and Tailwind CSS.

docs/components-in-depth/component-lifec.title: Component lifecycle
docs/components-in-depth/component-lifec.description: To see how component is handled by Drayman, let's take for example, a component which reads data from selected file and shows it to user:

docs/components-in-depth/default-props.title: Default props
docs/components-in-depth/default-props.description: defaultProps can be used to set default values for props. To set default values for props, export a defaultProps object from your component. This object will be merged with the props object passed to the component.

docs/components-in-depth/handling-events.title: Handling events
docs/components-in-depth/handling-events.description: Each element attribute which starts with an on prefix is considered by Drayman as an event. All events are fired in browser and then executed server-side (if you want to execute something insde browser, you can use Browser object).

docs/components-in-depth/helpers/force-u.title: forceUpdate
docs/components-in-depth/helpers/force-u.description: A forceUpdate is a function which calls a render function and sends a result to the user.

docs/components-in-depth/helpers/introdu.title: Introduction
docs/components-in-depth/helpers/introdu.description: Helper objects are passed by Drayman to component upon initialization.

docs/components-in-depth/helpers/the-com.title: The ComponentInstance object
docs/components-in-depth/helpers/the-com.description: The ComponentInstance object can be used to check component instance ID or handle lifecycle events.

docs/components-in-depth/helpers/the-eve.title: The EventHub object
docs/components-in-depth/helpers/the-eve.description: The EventHub object can be used to create a real-time communication between components.

docs/interactive-examples/file-viewer.title: File viewer
docs/interactive-examples/file-viewer.description: This example shows how to create a Drayman component which displays a file from file system. You can check a guide about it here.

docs/introduction/configuration.title: Configuration
docs/introduction/configuration.description: Drayman configuration can be managed inside drayman.config.js file.

docs/introduction/getting-started.title: Getting started
docs/introduction/getting-started.description: Drayman is a server-side component framework.

docs/introduction/server-and-client-comb.title: Server and client combined
docs/introduction/server-and-client-comb.description: Drayman allows using server-side and client-side code together. This allows you to easily combine server-side libraries, file-system queries, database connections, managing user-sensitive data and creating UI inside single script.

docs/postcss-and-tailwind-css.title: PostCSS and Tailwind CSS
docs/postcss-and-tailwind-css.description: If there is a PostCSS config somewhere (found by postcss-load-config), Drayman will automatically set it up.

docs/web-components/drayman-elements.title: @drayman/elements
docs/web-components/drayman-elements.description: @drayman/elements is an official collection of Web Components compatible with Drayman.

intro.title: Tutorial Intro
intro.description: Let's discover Docusaurus in less than 5 minutes.

README.title: Website
README.description: This website is built using Docusaurus 2, a modern static website generator.

src/pages/markdown-page.title: Markdown page example
src/pages/markdown-page.description: You don't need React to write simple standalone pages.

tutorial-basics/congratulations.title: Congratulations!
tutorial-basics/congratulations.description: You have just learned the basics of Docusaurus and made some changes to the initial template.

tutorial-basics/create-a-blog-post.title: Create a Blog Post
tutorial-basics/create-a-blog-post.description: Docusaurus creates a page for each blog post, but also a blog index page, a tag system, an RSS feed...

tutorial-basics/create-a-document.title: Create a Document
tutorial-basics/create-a-document.description: Documents are groups of pages connected through:

tutorial-basics/create-a-page.title: Create a Page
tutorial-basics/create-a-page.description: Add Markdown or React files to src/pages to create a standalone page:

tutorial-basics/deploy-your-site.title: Deploy your site
tutorial-basics/deploy-your-site.description: Docusaurus is a static-site-generator (also called Jamstack).

tutorial-basics/markdown-features.title: Markdown Features
tutorial-basics/markdown-features.description: Docusaurus supports Markdown and a few additional features.

tutorial-extras/manage-docs-versions.title: Manage Docs Versions
tutorial-extras/manage-docs-versions.description: Docusaurus can manage multiple versions of your docs.
